author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Aussie Farmers Unleash Dinosaur Rush as Fossil Findings Rewrite History
description: A new understanding of how to search for ancient remains has reinvigorated a region of western Queensland, with tourists flocking to paleontological digs.
content: It took a moment to spot the fragment, initially: fist-size and unnaturally smooth, nestled between shrubs teeming with burrs in an endless expanse of arid plains. But after the first, the others were easier to pick out, gleaming dirty white against the red earth and run through with a honeycomb texture.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 11, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 11, 2023.
content: An article last Sunday about the actress Greta Lee misstated when the second season of “Russian Doll” ended. It was last year, not in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oona A. Hathaway
title: What Donald Trump and Reality Winner Have in Common
description: The president’s own Justice Department vigorously enforced the Espionage Act, sending people to prison for much less than the actions described in his indictment.
content: Donald Trump is facing a 37-count indictment in federal court on charges connected to his retention of classified documents at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida. The charges include 31 counts of violating the Espionage Act for willfully retaining, without authorization, documents relating to national defense. As a former president with no formal security clearances, Mr. Trump no longer had a legal right to even view the documents, much less keep them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Melissa Etheridge’s Autobiographical Show Is Coming to Broadway
description: Combining stories from her life with her musical catalog, the singer’s show will open in September.
content: The singer-songwriter Melissa Etheridge’s theatrical memoir in which she weaves stories from her life will be staged on Broadway this fall, the production announced Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Ron DeSantis Thinks Trump Didn’t Go Far Enough
description: DeSantis is trying to show that he has both the will and the discipline to do what Trump did not.
content: Campaign books written by politicians are often dismissed as focus-grouped fluff. I disagree. You can learn a lot about people by paying close attention to how they want to be seen. And so it is with Ron DeSantis’s “The Courage to be Free.” It’s not a good book, exactly. But it is a revealing one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Jessie Maple, Pathbreaking Filmmaker, Is Dead at 86
description: She was believed to be the first Black woman to produce, write and direct an independent feature film. She also broke ground as a union cinematographer.
content: Jessie Maple, who built careers as a camerawoman and an independent filmmaker when Black women were almost nonexistent in those fields, and who then left meticulous instructions for later generations to follow in her footsteps, died on May 30 at her home in Atlanta. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Stolzberg
title: A Skating Affair
description: When her husband takes up a new interest, she begins to wonder what is really going on.
content: I heard a whisper: This is how it ends.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: The Refries That Bind: A Cavernous Cantina Returns
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 11th, 2023.
content: “It would be way cheaper if we just went hang gliding over volcanoes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Applegate
title: Their Pot Convictions Were Erased, but They Still Face Deportation
description: Immigrants convicted under the state’s discriminatory laws remain in legal limbo.
content: In 2019, New York decriminalized possession of small amounts of marijuana. Two years later, the state legalized recreational marijuana. The laws had the effect of automatically erasing certain low-level convictions related to the drug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Joni Mitchell Returns to the Stage, Golden, Glorious and in Control
description: The singer-songwriter’s first announced concert in more than 20 years was a nearly-three-hour reimagining of her catalog that showcased her evolving, rich voice and her ever-sharp wit.
content: “You’re stardust, and golden,” a beaming Joni Mitchell told a crowd of more than 20,000 on Saturday night at the scenic Washington venue the Gorge Amphitheater, during her first ticketed live performance in more than 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Thousands of Bylines to His Name, and One That’s Not
description: A sports reporter reflects on his 30-year career and the mistake that started it all.
content: It was the day after Christmas in 1991, and as a young journalist, I received quite a gift: my first byline in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Your Monday Briefing: Trump Indictment Unleashes Calls for Violence
description: Plus, a dinosaur rush in Australia.
content: The federal indictment of former President Donald Trump last week has unleashed a wave of calls by his supporters for violence and an uprising to defend him. The rhetoric is raising concerns of a dangerous atmosphere ahead of his court appearance in Miami tomorrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Tony Award Winners 2023: The Full List
description: The Tony Awards were held Sunday at the United Palace in New York City.
content: The 76th Tony Awards took place Sunday night at the United Palace in Manhattan’s Washington Heights neighborhood with the Oscar-winning actress Ariana DeBose as the host. The awards ceremony, which honored plays and musicals that opened on Broadway between April 29, 2022, and April 27, 2023, aired on CBS and on the streaming service Paramount+. A special segment, hosted by Julianne Hough and Skylar Astin, streamed on Pluto TV before the main ceremony, during which a number of awards, including recognitions for lifetime achievement and best original score, were announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Tens of Thousands of Dead Fish Wash Ashore on Gulf Coast in Texas
description: A “perfect storm” of bad conditions, including high temperatures, starved the fish of oxygen, officials said.
content: Tens of thousands of fish washed ashore along the gulf coast of Texas starting on Friday after being starved of oxygen in warm water, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: A New Festival Freely Dips Into Jazz and Classical Music
description: In its opening days, Ethan Iverson’s Sono Fest! in Brooklyn was already showing promise.
content: This past week, I did something with a classical music concert that I have often enjoyed at jazz clubs: I hung back to hear the same program again when it returned for a second set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Worth Remembering
description: In her New York Times Crossword debut, Alice Liang gets us talking.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: With Hollywood Change Stagnating, a Call to ‘Burn It Down’
description: The journalist Maureen Ryan is mad as hell about what goes on behind the entertainment-biz scenes. Her new book tells tales, and proposes remedies.
content: As I typed this, striking Writers Guild of America members were skipping the picket lines in New York City because of poor air quality, after smoke drifted down from wildfires in Canada. It was a grimly perfect backdrop to read “Burn It Down,” a new book about the pervasive moral shortcomings of Hollywood by the longtime entertainment reporter and critic Maureen Ryan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Kids Dance Puts on a Show of Courage, Discipline and Heart
description: Kids Dance, the performance group of Ballet Tech, returned to the Joyce with a mix of premieres and classics.
content: The roots of Ballet Tech’s Kids Dance took hold not in a dance studio but on the subway. It was 1977 when the choreographer Eliot Feld found himself sharing a train with elementary school children. To an ordinary person, they were just kids, but Feld saw something more: These were potential dancers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: How Walt Nauta, a Personal Aide, Came to Be Charged as Trump’s Co-Conspirator
description: A Navy veteran and a regular presence at Donald Trump’s side, he is said to have played a central role in helping to thwart government efforts to retrieve classified documents.
content: On May 25, as former President Donald J. Trump was at the Saudi-backed LIV Golf tournament at his course in Sterling, Va., one of his aides was photographed leaning toward him and dutifully adjusting the collar of his white pullover, a moment of closeness that had become routine for the pair.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cloisters U.: The Sounds of Silence in a College Class
description: Responses to Molly Worthen’s essay about removing technology from students’ daily lives. Also: Prizes in the arts; a climate question.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Adam Entous
title: A U.S. Citizen Has Been Arrested in Russia, State Department Says
description: The man, Michael Travis Leake, has been accused of drug trafficking, according to Russian state media.
content: An American citizen was arrested in Russia and was being detained in Moscow, the U.S. State Department said on Sunday. The man was accused of drug trafficking, according to Russian state media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir, Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Faceless, Nameless and Dead by the Dozen in a Train’s Cheapest Cars
description: In India’s worst railway disaster in decades, nearly all of the 288 dead were in three crowded cars where passengers stand for long stretches.
content: They cram themselves every day by the millions onto India’s overtaxed trains, chasing a shred of economic opportunity across the vastness of the world’s most populous nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Mahler, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Dan Farrell and Jake Young
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Most Dangerous Person in the World Is Randi Weingarten’
description: School closures and culture wars turned classrooms into battlegrounds — and made the head of one of the country’s largest teachers’ unions a lightning rod for criticism.
content: When the former secretary of state and C.I.A. director Mike Pompeo, a man who had dealt firsthand with autocrats like Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping, described Randi Weingarten as “the most dangerous person in the world” last November, it seemed as though he couldn’t possibly be serious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Summer Reading
description: Melissa Kirsch takes a look at some of the big books coming this summer.
content: The books are piling up again. The physical ones on the bedside table; the library queue; the e-bookshelves on which reside the novels impulse-purchased from bed, begun and then forgotten in one insomniac night. My eyes, always, bigger than my attention span.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Alan Feuer and Ben Protess
title: Trump Indictment Shows Critical Evidence Came From One of His Own Lawyers
description: M. Evan Corcoran, who was hired to represent the former president after the Justice Department issued a subpoena for classified documents at Mar-a-Lago, could be a key witness in the trial.
content: The two indictments filed so far against former President Donald J. Trump — one brought by the Manhattan district attorney, the other by a Justice Department special counsel — charge him with very different crimes but have something in common: Both were based, at least in part, on the words of his own lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Man Left Paralyzed in Police Encounter Gets $45 Million Settlement
description: Officials in New Haven, Conn., said the cost of the man’s continued health care was a major factor when deciding how much money to pay him.
content: A man who was paralyzed while being transported in the back of a police van will receive a $45 million payout, ending a legal battle against the city of New Haven, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Dana Rubinstein
title: A Pier Deal Is Full of Developer Perks, but Is It Good for the City?
description: Generous incentives will secure a project that keeps New York’s motion picture industry competitive, officials say. Critics call the price too steep.
content: Developers hoping to snap up big city real estate often persuade local officials to shower them with taxpayer-funded incentives to seal the deal and prevent them from taking their business elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
title: Their Reports About a Woman’s Death Set Off a Revolt. Iran Put Them on Trial.
description: Two female journalists, Niloufar Hamedi and Elaheh Mohammadi, covered some of the first reports of the death of Mahsa Amini in police custody, which ignited nationwide protests against Iran’s clerical rulers.
content: The Iranian journalist Niloufar Hamedi specialized in covering women’s issues. So when her editor noticed an Instagram post about a young woman in a hospital in bad shape after being arrested for violating the country’s strict Islamic dress code, Ms. Hamedi headed straight there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s Former Leader, Is Arrested in Financial Inquiry
description: The arrest of Ms. Sturgeon, who resigned as leader of the Scottish National Party in February, follows that of her husband, previously the party’s chief executive, and of its former treasurer.
content: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s former first minister and once one of Britain’s most prominent politicians, was arrested on Sunday by police officers investigating the finances of the Scottish National Party, which dominates the country’s politics and which she led until her unexpected resignation in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell and Ilana Marcus
title: The Failed Affirmative Action Campaign That Shook Democrats
description: The Supreme Court will soon rule on race-conscious college admissions, a core Democratic issue. But an analysis of a California referendum points to a divide between the party and voters.
content: The 2020 campaign to restore race-conscious affirmative action in California was close to gospel within the Democratic Party. It drew support from the governor, senators, state legislative leaders and a who’s who of business, nonprofit and labor elites, Black, Latino, white and Asian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Wagner Founder Rebuffs Order Over Fighter Contracts With Russian Military
description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the private military force, said he would not comply with an order that would require it to sign a formal contract with Russia’s defense ministry by July 1.
content: The leader of Russia’s Wagner private military company said Sunday that his group would not comply with an order that would require it to sign a formal contract with Russia’s defense ministry by July 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: Silicon Valley Confronts the Idea That the ‘Singularity’ Is Here
description: The frenzy over artificial intelligence may be ushering in the long-awaited moment when technology goes wild. Or maybe it’s the hype that is out of control.
content: For decades, Silicon Valley anticipated the moment when a new technology would come along and change everything. It would unite human and machine, probably for the better but possibly for the worse, and split history into before and after.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How the Head of a Theater Nonprofit Spends His Sundays
description: There is usually a matinee in store for Michael Presser, who is the founder of Inside Broadway.
content: More young people might be tuning into the Tony Awards this weekend thanks to the work of Michael Presser, the founder of Inside Broadway, a nonprofit organization that brings Broadway musicals to New York City schools and New York City schoolchildren to Broadway musicals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic Captures the French Open and a 23rd Grand Slam Title
description: Djokovic beat Casper Ruud to win the men’s singles championship, passing Rafael Nadal for the most major tournament titles in the Open era.
content: Novak Djokovic began his day picturing how it would end, holding his children in his arms, raising another Grand Slam tournament trophy above his head and singing his national anthem as Serbian fans chanted and danced and celebrated his third French Open men’s singles title and much more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine Claims First Gains, if Slight, in Counteroffensive
description: Three small settlements in the eastern region of Donetsk have been taken back from Russian occupiers, Ukrainian officials say.
content: After a week of mostly silence about its newly launched campaign to drive Russian occupying forces from Ukrainian territory, Ukraine’s military on Sunday claimed its first small gains as fighting raged in at least three sectors of the front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: A Firefighter Drowns After Rushing into the Sea to Save His Daughter
description: There were no lifeguards on duty at Avon-by-the-Sea, along the New Jersey shore, on Friday.
content: The day began with a dip into the cool Atlantic waters along the New Jersey shore near Avon-by-the-Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Fugazetta Is a Better Cheesy Bread
description: Ham El-Waylly’s recipe tops a cheese-stuffed focaccia calzone with a tangle of charred onions.
content: Good morning. There are many ways to dress up focaccia. You can top the bread with fruit or herbs (or fruit and herbs). You can cover it with potatoes and leeks. I like to split the bread and layer the interior with mortadella and pistachio cream, as they do at All’Antico Vinaio in Manhattan. In Argentina, home to a huge population of Italian immigrants, focaccia dough can be used to make fugazza, a kind of pizza hybrid topped with mozzarella, provolone and shaved onions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Newspapers Printed Unabomber’s Manifesto in 1995. It’s Still Fiercely Debated.
description: It wouldn’t be the last time the media would grapple with whether to publish something that might inspire others to take harmful actions.
content: In June 1995, hefty packages arrived in the mail rooms of The Washington Post and The New York Times with identical contents: single-space typed copies of a document called “Industrial Society and Its Future,” with a note from an anonymous sender who said he would kill again unless the newspapers published the manifesto in its entirety within 90 days.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Heard a Voice Coming From Behind a Nearby Stack of Books’
description: Taking shelter in the Strand, an encounter with a very tall man and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: I-95 Overpass Collapses in Philadelphia After a Tanker Fire
description: Officials urged commuters to be patient as Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania warned that repairs might last “some number of months.”
content: Part of Interstate 95 in northeast Philadelphia was shut down in both directions early on Sunday morning after a tanker truck believed to be carrying gasoline caught fire, causing part of the highway to collapse, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira A. Scheindlin
title: If the Supreme Court Abolishes Affirmative Action, Here’s What Women Need to Do
description: These programs have historically benefited women more than anyone else. Now they must help others in underrepresented communities.
content: Any day now the Supreme Court will decide two cases that will determine the future of affirmative action — one involving race-conscious admissions at the University of North Carolina and a companion case involving Harvard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: ‘Everything Will Die’: A Dam Blast Imperils Ukraine’s Vital Lifeline
description: A disaster unfolds in slow motion after an explosion destroyed the dam at the Kakhovka Reservoir, emptying its waters and threatening livelihoods and crucial industries.
content: The view from villagers’ gardens on the northern shore of the Kakhovka Reservoir has changed significantly in the four days since an explosion destroyed the nearby dam and the waters receded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Martell
title: It’s All Fun and Games Until Someone Gets Hurt
description: Always looking for an edge, some batters stand their ground and let pitches hit them. As Pete Alonso’s wrist injury shows, the downside can be extreme.
content: In the movie “Moneyball,” Peter Brand, a baseball analyst played by Jonah Hill, has a mantra for the type of player his team covets. “He gets on base,” Brand says when his boss points at him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: Hands Bound, but Still Reporting
description: A pair of zip-tie cuffs, on display in the Museum at The Times, serve as a stark reminder of the risk and significance of on-the-ground journalism.
content: Some journalists who covered the protests over the killing of Daunte Wright in April 2021 worked under an extra hardship: Their hands were tied behind their backs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Owen Gingerich, Astronomer Who Saw God in the Cosmos, Dies at 93
description: He wrote and lectured widely, often on the theme that religion and science were not incompatible. He also chased down 600 copies of Copernicus’s landmark book.
content: Owen Gingerich, a noted astronomer who was particularly interested in the history of his field — so much so that he spent years trying to track down every first- and second-edition copy of Nicolaus Copernicus’s revolutionary treatise — and who was not shy about giving God credit for a role in creating the cosmos he loved to study, died on May 28 in Belmont, Mass. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Review: At the Royal Ballet, a Landscape and Soundscape With Dance
description: Wayne McGregor’s new ballet, “Untitled, 2023,” gives equal weight to Carmen Herrera’s visual design and Anna Thorvaldsdottir’s music.
content: LONDON — It’s been 17 years since the Royal Ballet named Wayne McGregor its resident choreographer in 2006. McGregor came from a contemporary dance background and had little experience working with ballet companies, but Monica Mason, then the Royal’s director, recognized McGregor’s ranging curiosity about the physical capacities of the body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt, Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Adam Goldman
title: Trump Supporters’ Violent Rhetoric in His Defense Disturbs Experts
description: The former president’s allies have portrayed the indictment as an act of war and called for retribution, which political violence experts say increases the risk of action.
content: The federal indictment of former President Donald J. Trump has unleashed a wave of calls by his supporters for violence and an uprising to defend him, disturbing observers and raising concerns of a dangerous atmosphere ahead of his court appearance in Miami on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Why Secrets Lost Their Sizzle
description: Unlike previous leaks, the revelations in the “Discord Leaks” have largely failed to capture the American public’s attention.
content: In April, secret documents allegedly photographed by a member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard began making their way into the mainstream media. Many were briefings prepared by military intelligence services, and much of it dealt with the Russia-Ukraine war. They offered Americans a rare window into the government’s most valuable intelligence on one of Europe’s deadliest conflicts since World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Dederer
title: When Truth No Longer Counts, How Does a Memoirist Tell Her Story?
description: This is the question at the heart of “To Name the Bigger Lie,” by Sarah Viren, which tries to make sense of two disturbing episodes from her life in the context of a culture where truth itself is increasingly in dispute.
content: It’s an experience I’m betting most of us have had over the last decade: the creeping feeling that a common truth no longer exists. Where once there were facts, now there is strife. Where once there was one America, now there are two. (At least.) Where once there were agreed-upon narratives, now there are competing stories, falsehoods and deceptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Ken Bensinger
title: The 2024 G.O.P. Field Faces a Choice: Law and Order or Loyalty
description: The candidates challenging Donald Trump have to decide how to run against the indicted former president. And it could determine where the party goes from here.
content: The federal indictment of former President Donald J. Trump has left the Republican Party — and his rivals for the party’s nomination — with a stark choice between deferring to a system of law and order that has been central to the party’s identity for half a century or a more radical path of resistance, to the Democratic Party in power and to the nation’s highest institutions that Mr. Trump now derides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Emily Morse Wants You to Think Seriously About an Open Relationship
description: “You need to be self-aware and have self-knowledge about your sexual desires,” the sex therapist, author and podcaster says.
content: “You need to be self-aware and have self-knowledge about your sexual desires,” the sex therapist, author and podcaster says.
source.name: The New York Times
